message_1:
Suppose that $E$ is a vector bundle over a base space $X$ such that each fiber $E_x$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{R}^n$ for some fixed $n$. Let $\pi : E \rightarrow X$ be the projection map. If $U$ and $V$ are two open sets in $X$, with $U\cap V \neq \varnothing$, let $f$ and $g$ be two continuous functions that satisfy $f|_{U\cap V} = g|_{U\cap V}$. 

Prove that there exists a continuous section $s: X \rightarrow E$ such that $s(x) \in \pi^{-1}(x)$ and $s(x)|_U = f(x)$ and $s(x)|_V = g(x)$.
message_2:
To prove the existence of such a continuous section $s$, we will define $s$ on $U$ and $V$ separately and then show that it is continuous on their intersection.

Define $s: X \rightarrow E$ as follows:

$$
s(x) = \begin{cases}
f(x) & \text{if } x \in U \\
g(x) & \text{if } x \in V
\end{cases}
$$

Note that $s(x) \in \pi^{-1}(x)$ for all $x \in X$, since both $f$ and $g$ map into the fibers of $E$.

Now we need to show that $s$ is continuous. Since $f$ and $g$ are continuous on $U$ and $V$ respectively, it suffices to show that $s$ is continuous on $U \cap V$. 

Let $x \in U \cap V$. Since $f|_{U\cap V} = g|_{U\cap V}$, we have $f(x) = g(x)$. Thus, $s(x) = f(x) = g(x)$ for all $x \in U \cap V$. 

Let $W$ be an open neighborhood of $s(x)$ in $E$. Since $f$ and $g$ are continuous, there exist open neighborhoods $U_f$ and $U_g$ of $x$ in $U$ and $V$ respectively such that $f(U_f) \subseteq W$ and $g(U_g) \subseteq W$. Let $U_x = U_f \cap U_g \cap (U \cap V)$. Then $U_x$ is an open neighborhood of $x$ in $U \cap V$. 

For any $y \in U_x$, we have $y \in U_f$ and $y \in U_g$. Thus, $s(y) = f(y) \in W$ and $s(y) = g(y) \in W$. Therefore, $s(U_x) \subseteq W$. This shows that $s$ is continuous at $x$. Since $x \in U \cap V$ was arbitrary, $s$ is continuous on $U \cap V$.

Hence, $s$ is a continuous section of $E$ such that $s(x)|_U = f(x)$ and $s(x)|_V = g(x)$.
